text.tspan: a unifying reference system for spatio-temporal datasets
* Compact binary data storage, extensible metadata
* Fast random and parallel access, efficient, scalable
* Widely used in High Performance Computing
* HDF5 libraries exists for many languages
such as Python, Matlab, Java, C++
* A convention of the hierarchical layout used to store
* A convention on how to represent geometric data
types with N-dimensional homogeneous arrays with
* A recommendation for a core set of metadata fields
with the option to include XML-based data models
* Foster the usage of OBO concepts [obofoundry.org]
Affine transformation defines the local coordinate system
of the Region. Regular and irregular datasets are components
of the Region and can define their own transformation relative
to the Region. The required information is mapped to the
Regions can be nested, defining multi-scale data space
representations in terms of spatial resolution.
Clear separation between geometry and their interpretation:
x_unit, y_unit, z_unit : mm, mm, mm
The Connectome File Format (CFF) integrates several community accepted data formats using an XML-based container description.
These data formats are very different in the way they separate data and metadata, and how they structure and represent binary
data in files. Customized reader and writer libraries have to be developed across platform and programming languages for each
binary data format, some of the formats are text-based thus lack random access and store data inefficently.
Here, we propose to extract the common underlying structure of data types for neuroscientific datasets produced across a wide
variety of spatio-temporal scales and conceptual granularities, in order to define a hierarchical data layout to integrate binary data
with metadata using Hierarchical Data Format (HDF5) as data container.
Neuroinformatics will have to provide generic solutions for storage and exchange for large amounts of complex neuroscience data.
In the bioinformatics community, BioHDF [www.biohdf.org] is developed along similar lines to handle the massive amounts of
data produced by next generation sequencing methods.
N-dimensional arrays with spatial, temporal and other dimensions
Examples: microscopy, MRI, gene expression, electrophysiology
Examples: networks, behavioral experiments, simulation results
Two classes of datasets: a) spatio-temporal datasets
which are mapped meaningfully to a spatial
coordinate system, b) generic datasets without a
